channel.title: BBC News - Business

item.title: Unpaid state pension: 'I'm disgusted by delays'
item.description: Thousands of people who have turned 66 have not been paid their state pensions and they are furious.

item.title: Carbon dioxide 'threatens food security' says meat industry
item.description: A shortage of the gas could hit meat production and packaging, UK processors warn.

item.title: Travel rule changes 'positive', say airlines
item.description: Simplifying the traffic light system and reducing testing requirements will boost the industry, airlines say.

item.title: Next deal keeps Gap brand alive in the UK
item.description: Deal means Gap will still have a UK High Street presence within Next's stores despite closing its own.

item.title: Broadcasting cash offsets Man Utd's Covid losses
item.description: Football giant says year was among its most challenging but sees broadcast income jump sharply.

item.title: Shop sales fall for fourth month as more dine out
item.description: Sales at food stores fell last month as more people spent their money in restaurants and bars.

item.title: 'I’m constantly worried about being evicted'
item.description: Debt charity StepChange is calling for emergency support for renters who have fallen behind on payments.

item.title: UK travel update: Overhaul of 'traffic light' rules due
item.description: The transport secretary is expected to announce an overhaul of the "traffic light" system.

item.title: China applies to join key Asia-Pacific trade pact
item.description: It comes the day after a regional security agreement between the US, UK and Australia was unveiled.

item.title: John Lewis charters ships to ensure Christmas stock arrives
item.description: The department store chain says it is trying everything to get goods to the UK for the holiday season.

item.title: Carbon emitters 'failing to disclose climate risks'
item.description: In a study of more than 100 company accounts, 80% of audits didn't assess climate risk.

item.title: Sir Clive Sinclair: Computing pioneer dies aged 81
item.description: The inventor, entrepreneur and ZX Spectrum creator died at his London home following a long illness.

item.title: E.On boss: Remove green levies to cut energy bills
item.description: Cut soaring energy costs by paying energy levies through taxes, E.On UK boss Michael Lewis says.

item.title: Most workers do not expect full-time office return, survey says
item.description: Most people do not believe workers will return to the office full-time, according to YouGov research.

item.title: Vectura: Marlboro giant seals takeover of UK inhaler firm
item.description: Philip Morris International clinches its £1.1bn bid for the UK inhaler firm Vectura.

item.title: Marks & Spencer blames Brexit as it closes 11 French stores
item.description: Brexit has made it "near impossible" for it to supply fresh and chilled products to France, the retailer says.

item.title: Southwest Airlines pays staff extra to get jabbed
item.description: It is the latest big carrier to offer incentives for getting vaccinated as US infections surge.

item.title: Co-op to start selling groceries on Amazon Prime
item.description: Shoppers will be able to order Co-op's full range of groceries via Amazon across the UK by Christmas.

item.title: Five ways we think office work will change
item.description: How people think the coronavirus pandemic has affected the future of office work in five charts.

item.title: Asos and Primark set out new green pledges
item.description: The chains says their clothes will stay reasonably priced but will be more sustainably produced.

item.title: 'Looking back, it was an amazing thing I did'
item.description: Meet the founder on a 10-year mission to disrupt Japan's rigid work culture.

item.title: Gen Z battles to bring back unions, one Starbucks at a time
item.description: Younger Americans are reviving US labour activism amid stagnant wages and Covid hardship.

item.title: Why taking up an instrument has struck a chord for so many
item.description: The pandemic led to around 1m UK adults learning an instrument and many taking music lessons.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'You can run a business and have a baby'
item.description: Planning for a maternity leave when you're the boss of a fast-growing company.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Amazon's Cape Town base: The battle to save South African culture
item.description: Some indigenous groups say the planned office in Cape Town is on culturally important land.

item.title: The pressures - and rewards - of being an influencer
item.description: Running your own popular YouTube channel can be lucrative, but it comes with downsides.

item.title: The epicentre of Britain's pandemic house price boom
item.description: House prices have surged in many parts of the UK - and in one district they have risen by 29% in a year.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: Women's state pension: 'It is like you've lived one big lie'
item.description: How women born in the 1950s had their retirement plans upended by state pension age changes.

item.title: How a monkey launched the pop-it toy craze
item.description: Why it took a TikTok primate to turn a forty-year-old idea into a global hit

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: CEO Secrets: The bra boss busting stereotypes
item.description: Leanne Cahill, CEO of Bravissimo, shares her journey from shop floor to boardroom in retail.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.
